text: everybody Thomas shows up here and today
we are tackling one of the most popular
conundrums and that is fudge now a lot
of you have asked hey
my fudge when I make it at home it turns
out really dry and brittle like this
version I have here or it's too soft and
it's really difficult to cut well today
I'm going to share with you a few tricks
and tips and making fudge at home and
I'm sure the next time you make it you
will have success
the first step in making fudge at home
is to chop up your chocolate now I'm
using three ounces of semi-sweet
chocolate here today and it is really
important if you're making this
confection at home that you use a really
high quality chocolate so buy the best
chocolate you can find and we're really
only using a little bit of it three
ounces to be exact so you know splurge
go to the grocery store or your
specialty shop and buy a really great
quality chocolate now I'm chopping this
up into nice fine chunks and whenever
you're working with chocolate or your
melting chocolate it's always best to
cut the chocolate and nice even small
pieces all right
so chocolate is nice and fine here I
have two cups of granulated sugar and I
also have three tablespoons of cocoa
powder now this is the best quality
cocoa powder we could find
it's Dutch process cocoa powder meaning
it's treated with an alkaline solution
and it's usually much darker in color so
in the end your fudge will have this
really really rich color and also really
great flavor to go along with it as well
so I'm gonna sift these two ingredients
together just to break up any clumps
that you might have in the sugar or the
cocoa powder and this recipe is really
interesting because it does use cocoa
powder a lot of traditional fudge
recipes really just rely on chocolate
for the flavoring but I find that the
cocoa powder really does go that extra
mile in adding a lot of really great
richness and depth of flavor and then
this mixture is going into our sauce pot
so I have a nice tall sauce pot here on
my burner I'm gonna add the cocoa sugar
mixture
two thirds of a cup of whole milk right
into the pot here and I'm gonna turn
this on a low heat and just mix these
three ingredients together until the
sugar has dissolved with the milk and
now I'm going to add two tablespoons of
corn syrup and corn syrup is really
great here in fudge making because it
helps to prevent crystallization so
we're gonna cook this mixture together
and often
times when you have something that's so
high in sugar that you're cooking down
you're boiling down you run the risk of
crystallization happening in the pot so
this corn syrup will kind of help in
preventing it one of the methods in
helping to prevent that in addition to
the corn syrup I'm also going to add a
little bit of butter this is two
tablespoons of unsalted butter and this
goes right into the pot and last but not
least I'm gonna add the three ounces of
chopped chocolate now again over a low
heat we're gonna melt this together
until the chocolate is evenly combined
with the rest of the ingredients and
that will take anywhere from seven to
ten minutes all right so it's been a few
minutes here and the butter has
completely melted the chocolate pieces
are melted as well and the sugar I can
feel it with the spatula is almost
completely dissolved and at this point
what I want to do is I'm going to crank
the heat up on this chocolate mixture
and I'm going to use a candy thermometer
now to monitor the temperature of this
mixture so I really want this mixture to
come up to 236 degrees and I'm going to
essentially boil this down concentrating
the mixture and this is a necessary step
here guys in creating a rich decadent
fudge that is not going to be too too
soft you need to make sure that you're
achieving this high temperature of 236
degrees and that will ensure that the
fudge will set properly while this is
boiling a few tips in making sure that
this mixture doesn't really crystallize
on you you can similar to how you would
make a caramel use a pastry brush and
brush down the sides of the pan as it
boils and this will ensure that no sugar
crystals are developing around the
outside or the perimeter of the pan and
will give you a nice silken texture to
your fudge so this is gonna take a
little bit of time here guys and while
this is boiling it's really helpful to
have a nice ice bath on hand because
once this hits that temperature we're
looking for we want to stop the cooking
process and I'm going to then take the
and go right into this ice bath and that
will eliminate the temperature from
increasing or inhibit the temperature
from increasing we are almost at 236
degrees which is the temperature we're
looking for now I'm using two different
thermometers here and a good way to see
if your thermometer is calibrated
properly is to either stick it in some
boiling water and it should reach 212
degrees Fahrenheit or you could put it
in a bucket of ice water and it should
read 32 degrees Fahrenheit so it's a
great way to check to see whether or not
your thermometer is reading properly so
we are almost there guys with this
temperature we're at 235 we have one
degree to go and again this is really an
important step in making a fudge at home
that's going to set properly there we go
we're at 236 so I'm going to turn this
off and I'm going to place this pan
right in my bowl of ice water here again
just for a few seconds to stop the
cooking process so this fudge won't go
any higher than 236 degrees and now I'm
gonna remove it from the ice bath and we
are going to let this chocolate mixture
sit here at room temperature we're gonna
let this cool down to about 121 degrees
and you want it at this point to leave
it completely undisturbed you don't want
to agitate this or stir it at all and
once it's cooled we're gonna go to the
process of giving it a vigorous stir to
lighten it and fluff up the fudge so
that it has the texture that we all know
and love
now fudge is really fantastic because
you can add so many different things to
it you could add different flavorings to
it I'm gonna add some toasted walnuts
today to my fudge but you can use any
type of nuts that you like I would
always encourage you to toast them
before adding because they have even
more flavor you could add a little bit
of vanilla some people like peppermint
you could add chocolate chips or chunks
or peanut butter chips it's really up to
you you can customize this in so many
different ways alright guys so our
temperature has reached 121 degrees so
this is cooled off enough I'm gonna
remove the thermometer so now at this
point I'm going to take a wooden spoon
and stir this mixture
continuously vigorously but not beating
up the fudge mixture and I'm gonna
continue to stir this for two to three
minutes until the nice shiny fudge it
becomes a little bit matte and that's
when you know that you're done stirring
and what this does is it creates that
wonderful silky texture it also kind of
helps to kind of lighten and aerate the
mixture a little bit but if you do over
stir this if you go too far and you'll
notice the mixture will start to thicken
as you stir it what will happen is the
mixture will get really grainy and
coarse and then in the end you'll end up
with a grainy fudge so this is the part
where you really need to kind of take
care and sometimes it takes a little bit
of practice but if you use kind of the
visual cues that we keep telling you
about the shininess to that matte finish
on the chocolate
you should have success okay guys so
it's been about three to four minutes
here and you can see that the chocolate
mixture it's gone from a really shiny
silky color to something that's a little
bit more dull it's not as glossy and
it's definitely more viscous and you can
kind of hear it too when you stir it
kind of slaps around the pan a little
bit and at this point I'm going to add
my walnuts these are toasted walnuts
that are broken into decent sized pieces
and I just want to stir this together
until the walnuts are incorporated now
the one thing I just want to tell you to
be careful of is that you shouldn't add
anything into this mixture that's cold
otherwise that's gonna shock the fudge
and you'll end up with something that is
kind of grainy or coarse and texture so
now this is ready I'm going to pour it
right into our lined pan this is again
buttered and lined with parchment and I
like to use the overhang on the
parchment so that it helps you to get
the fudge out of the pan easily you can
take an offset spatula and smooth out
the fudge so you get it into all of the
nice corners here so that it has a nice
even shape to it and then I like to
cover this with plastic wrap and this is
gonna go into the refrigerator for about
30 minutes now alternatively you could
let this rest on the countertop until
it's nice and set but you can also
just pop it into the fridge for a little
bit until it's nice and firm and we will
be able to pop this out of the pan and
cut it so into the fridge okay guys so
this has been in the refrigerator for
about 30 minutes and I popped it out of
the pan it's really easy to get out with
that parchment overhang and now you can
cut this into whatever size pieces your
you're looking for you could even if you
wanted to be fancy cut these out using a
cookie cutter into nice figural shapes
but today I think I'm just going to cut
these into little squares and if you're
gonna cut these and gift them or if
you're going to present them it's always
nice to put them in little paper cups
just so that people don't get their
hands too dirty the great thing here you
guys about this recipe is that it works
if you follow those instructions
remember to make sure that you're
bringing your sugar and chocolate
mixture up to 236 degrees and that will
help to make the fudge set nicely so
it's easily sliceable and then cooling
it down without disturbing it to 121
